data.title: ‚Ä¶What Someone Wrote Down
data.meta_description: Posts about author written by Bronwyn Mroz Benson
data.text:
It‚Äôs been two months since I said I was coming back, and I‚Äôm finally ready! As of right now I plan on a post a month, but hope to increase posting as I get back into the swing of things. For today‚Ä¶ Enjoy!

You may not have heard of Anita Loos before, but I‚Äôm sure you know of her most famous work. It‚Äôs a slight little book, but it had a sequel, was made into a musical, and then that was made into a movie. You know the actress that sang the film‚Äôs popular song. Or you probably know the ‚Äô80s pop star that used the scene as inspiration for a video. Or the early 2000s jukebox movie musical that used the song.

Gentlemen Prefer Blondes is what Loos is known for these days, if you know her at all, but she was a force behind the scenes of the early twentieth century‚Äôs film industry.

Anita Loos was born in California on April 26, 1888, to Richard and Minerva, ‚ÄúMinnie‚Äù. Richard founded a tabloid paper, while Minnie did most of the work of the publisher. The family moved around a lot, and at age three the family (also including Anita‚Äôs brother and sister) moved to San Francisco. Her father bought a police gazette paper, The Dramatic Event, with money that Minnie borrowed from her dad. Anita loved going around with her father while he did work for the paper. She loved the underbelly of San Francisco and its ‚Äúlowlifes and loose women‚Äù. In 1897, Anita and her sister, Gladys, performed with the San Francisco stock company in a production of Quo Vadis. Gladys died at age eight, but Anita kept performing, becoming the main breadwinner for the family. In 1903, her father started managing a theater company in San Diego. Anita performed in the company, as well as with another more legitimate theater company.

After graduating from San Diego high school, Anita figured out a way to get published. She scoured newspapers for tidbits about New York society, wrote up little snippets, and had a friend in New York submit them for publication in San Diego papers. Anita‚Äôs father also encouraged her writing, specifically plays. She wrote The Ink Well, which would sporadically earn her royalties.

Throughout this time, Anita was still performing. Theaters would show short films after plays and she fell in love. She would hurry to change clothes so she could come back out and enjoy the films. Between this love of film and her love to write, it was only natural that she began to try her hand at writing screenplays. Her first attempt was He Was a College Boy. She sent it off to the Biograph Company (home to D. W. Griffith, Mary Pickford, and Lillian Gish) and made $25. It wasn‚Äôt until her third script, 1912‚Äôs The New York Hat, before one of her screenplays was produced, starring Mary Pickford and Lionel Barrymore.

Between 1912 and 1915, Anita wrote 105 scripts ‚Äì 101 of them were produced. She mined her own life experiences and those of people around her for her screenplays. She wrote 200 screenplays before she even visited a film studio.

Also in 1915, Anita married Frank Pallma, Jr., the son of a band conductor. Her mother did not approve, but Anita was trying to escape her mother and didn‚Äôt care. However, six months later, like something out of one of her screenplays or novels, Anita sent Frank out for hairpins, packed up, and left him while he was out. After this, Minnie was more understanding, and even went to D. W. Griffith‚Äôs ‚Äúfilm colony‚Äù with Anita.

With Griffith at Triangle Film Corporation, Anita was paid $75 a week, with bonuses when her scripts were produced. Not many were produced, but they were funny, so she was encouraged to continue. With Griffith, Anita worked on the intertitles for 1916‚Äôs Intolerance, even traveling to New York for its premiere. While in New York, Anita met Frank Crowninshield of Vanity Fair. She would contribute to Vanity Fair for decades.

Griffith was leaving Triangle and Anita moved back to California. There she started working with the director John Emerson on a number of pictures for Douglas Fairbanks. The five movies she wrote for Fairbanks turned him into a star; he was offered a deal with Famous Players-Lasky and brought Anita and Emerson with him at $500 a week. Anita earned the nickname ‚ÄúThe Soubrette of Satire‚Äù from Photoplay magazine.

In 1918, Anita and Emerson were offered an even better deal with Famous Players-Lasky if they went to New York. These films did nothing for Anita‚Äôs career. Without Hollywood stars, they were cast with Broadway actors who just didn‚Äôt work in movies the same way. Anita was working very hard and Emerson ‚Äútook all the money and most of the credit.‚Äù By now though, Anita was in love with him and let him.

In 1919, William Randolph Hearst asked Anita to write something for Marion Davies. She wrote Getting Mary Married, which became one of Davies‚Äô few films that didn‚Äôt lose money. The following year, Anita and Emerson co-authored the book How to Write Photoplays, followed by Breaking into the Movies in 1921. Anita was offered more work writing for Davies, but turned it down to work with Constance Talmadge and Joseph Schenck (he was married to Constance‚Äôs sister, Norma). She wrote two movies for them, both of which were hits, A Temperamental Wife and A Virtuous Vamp.

Anita and Constance became fast friends, Constance filling the void left by Anita‚Äôs sister. They shopped together all the time and Anita was invited on vacation to Paris with the Talmadge-Schenck family. Much of this trip worked its way into Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. On returning to America, Anita worked on five more films and finally divorced her first husband (yes, she was still married to the guy she sent out for hairpins). John Emerson then proposed. They were married at Schenck‚Äôs estate on June 15, 1919. Anita was an early member of the Lucy Stone League and kept her own name.

Anita and Emerson cut back on how many films they were working on and traveled. They spent a lot of time in Paris, visiting with writers Anita had met previously who were now Paris-based, as well as Gertrude Stein, Alice B. Toklas, Elisabeth Marbury, Elsie de Wolfe, and others.

Emerson continued to be a‚Ä¶ struggle for Anita. Once a week, he took a break from their marriage and dated younger women. Anita consoled herself with the company of her ‚ÄúTuesday Widows‚Äù ‚Äì friends, actresses, dancers, and chorus girls who were kept by rich men. These women influenced her future writings and introduced her to Harlem, sparking a deep life-long love of black culture. In her 1977 book, Cast of Thousands, Anita wrote of this time: ‚ÄúSometimes I get enquiries [sic] concerning my marriage to a man who treated me with complete lack of consideration, tried to take credit for my work and appropriated all my earnings ‚Ä¶ The main reason is that my husband liberated me; granted me full freedom to choose my own companions.‚Äù

Around this same time, Anita became a follower of H. L. Mencken. If he was in New York, she‚Äôd take a break from her ‚ÄúTuesday Widows‚Äù and join Mencken‚Äôs circle (which included Theodore Dreiser, Sherwood Anderson, and Sinclair Lewis, among others). Anita quickly learned, though, that these sorts of gentlemen didn‚Äôt go for smart women, but those with other‚Ä¶ attributes. On a train with Mencken once, Anita watched him try and pick up a blonde in their dining car. She quickly wrote some sketches, picking on Mencken and these ‚Äòblondes‚Äô.

Initially the sketches were published in Harper‚Äôs Bazaar, but quickly took off, increasing the magazine‚Äôs circulation and having people clamoring for more. In November 1925, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes was published, selling out its first printing almost immediately. As with anything too popular, though, reviewers weren‚Äôt impressed. Word of mouth propelled the book along and it went through twenty printings in its first decade. Eventually it would go through 85 editions and was translated into at least 14 languages.

Gentlemen Prefer Blondes was turned into a stage play almost immediately. In 1926 it opened in Chicago and lasted 201 performances on Broadway. In 1928, the first film version was released, with Ruth Taylor playing the lead, Lorelei Lee. Unfortunately this was a bit of a flop.

Emerson had tried to stop Anita from publishing the book, but settled for its dedication instead. Afterwards, he ‚Äúfell ill‚Äù and Anita was blamed. He was a hypochondriac and put on laryngitis to keep attention on himself. Anita was already working on a sequel to Blondes and promised to stop working after it was complete. She and Emerson were supposed to travel to Europe together, but he didn‚Äôt feel like it and sent her on alone. He grew jealous of the fun she was having without him and traveled over to join her. In 1927, But Gentlemen Marry Brunettes was published, and the couple traveled in Europe extensively.

(After hearing about it and buying it at least a decade ago, I finally read Blondes and Brunettes last month. The Penguin edition I have includes both, as well as an introduction and a great preface by Anita Loos from after Blondes had taken off. Guys, it‚Äôs really funny. Blondes is a diary format and travelogue. Lorelei tells her story over about six months, I think, and it‚Äôs rife with her misspellings and misunderstandings and it‚Äôs really charming. Brunettes is Lorelei relating the story of her friend, Dorothy. I didn‚Äôt find it as funny, but it‚Äôs still really enjoyable. I highly recommend them both. I‚Äôve added them to my list of lesser known 1920s classics. Related, have you heard of Ursual Parrott? You should also read Ursula Parrott.)

With the stock market crash in 1929, Emerson lost a lot and suggested Anita start working again. She wanted to, having missed it. She worked on a stage adaptation of Brunettes, as well as writing a play, Cherries are Ripe. Around this same time, Anita came across a love letter written to Emerson. She asked him for a divorce. He refused, but they began living apart. When the couple was offered a deal to write for MGM, she went without him.

Anita was brought in to fix Red-Headed Woman, a script that had been started by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Anita worked her magic and the film was finished in May 1932. The film was a huge success and made Jean Harlow a star. One advertising campaign played on Anita‚Äôs fame, with Harlow holding a book of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes with Blondes crossed out and Red-Heads written in. Anita‚Äôs success, once again, drew Emerson back. While he continued to do nothing, he was a good face for the studios and directors who much preferred working with a man.

In 1935, Anita paired with Robert Hopkins. Their script, San Francisco, received an Oscar nomination, and the pair continued to work together afterwards. In 1937, Anita did not renew her contract with MGM, signing instead with United Artists. She regretted it almost immediately and wound up buying herself out of her contract and re-signing with MGM.

Around this same time, Anita and her brother, now a doctor, checked Emerson into a sanatorium where he was diagnosed with schizophrenia. In 1937, she again asked for a divorce. This time Emerson agreed, but wouldn‚Äôt cooperate with anything, making its finalization impossible. They remained married until his death in 1956.

Anita worked steadily for MGM through World War II, but was later released from her contract. She returned to New York where she worked on Happy Birthday, a comedic play for Helen Hayes. It opened poorly in Boston, but Anita kept tweaking it and New York loved it.

In 1949, a musical of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes opened with Carol Channing. It made Channing a star and only shut down two years later when Channing became pregnant. In 1953, the film of the musical was released. Anita wasn‚Äôt involved, but loved the casting of Marilyn Monroe as Lorelei Lee.

Anita‚Äôs profile continued to rise. She wrote another novel (it did poorly) and worked on a stage adaptation of Colette‚Äôs Gigi. The play ran from the fall of 1951 to the spring of 1952. Colette had discovered Audrey Hepburn and recommended her for the role; the play made her a star. In 1959, Anita adapted another Colette story, Ch√©ri, but it only ran for two months.

Throughout this time and the next decades, Anita kept writing for magazines. She also worked on two memoirs, A Girl Like I (about silent films and early Hollywood) and Kiss Hollywood Goodbye (about working for MGM). In 1978 she published a biography of the Talmadge sisters, The Talmadge Girls.

Anita didn‚Äôt slow down until her eyesight and hearing started to go. In 1981, Anita spent several weeks with a lung infection. Eventually she had a heart attack and died at Doctor‚Äôs Hospital in Manhattan on August 18, 1981, at the age of 93. At her memorial, friends, Helen Hayes, Ruth Gordon, Lillian Gish, and more, told anecdotes about Anita. Julie Styne played songs from Anita‚Äôs musicals, including ‚ÄúDiamonds are a Girl‚Äôs Best Friend.‚Äù

This week I don‚Äôt have cool pictures I took myself regarding this week‚Äôs subject, the author Halld√≥r Laxness. We tried really, really hard though, and it‚Äôs kind of a funny story. My mom looked up where Laxness is buried on Find A Grave, a pretty good site for that sort of thing. Find A Grave says he‚Äôs in Fossvogskirkjugar√∞ur, in Reykjavik. Getting there was in and of itself an adventure and a pain, but we finally made it. We had the picture from Find A Grave to go on and we were all set. It fairly quickly became apparent that this was not where Laxness is buried. Fossvogskirkjugar√∞ur is very woodsy and, while over a sort of bay, there‚Äôs no way that you can see mountains and a river and all that, like in the picture from the website. Fossvogskirkjugar√∞ur is very pretty and has some really neat stuff, but it‚Äôs not what we were looking for, so we called it a night.

After googling and finding the Wikimedia Commons link, we find out that he‚Äôs actually buried in the cemetery at Mossfellskirkja in Mossfellsdalur ‚Äì near Reykjavik, but not workable in the time we had left in the area. So, no actual pictures from me of anything Laxness-related. This one is from Find A Grave (so you can see what we were looking for!). I was told, though, that a building we walked by down the main street in Reykjavik is where he was born, but my cousin wasn‚Äôt quite sure of the exact building, so no photo of that either. On to the actual, brief history of Halld√≥r Laxness.

Halld√≥r Kiljan Laxness was born Halld√≥r Gu√∞j√≥nsson on April 23, 1902 in Reykjavik, Iceland. His family lived in Reykjavik until 1905, when they moved out of town to Mosfellsb√¶r. I didn‚Äôt find a whole lot on young Halld√≥r, but it is known that he was writing from a young age. In the winter of 1915-1916, Laxness went to the technical school in Reykjavik, and in 1916 he published his first piece, an article, in the newspaper Morgunbla√∞i√∞. A few years later, in 1919, Laxness published his first novel, Barn n√°tt√∫runnar: √°starsaga (Child of Nature: A Romance). Around this same time, Laxness began travelling through Europe.

This was a crucial point in Laxness‚Äôs life in that this is when he went from Halld√≥r Gu√∞j√≥nsson to Halld√≥r Kiljan Laxness. In 1922, Laxness joined the Abbaye Saint-Maurice-et-Saint-Maur in Luxembourg, and in 1923 he was baptized and confirmed in the Catholic Church as Halld√≥r Kiljan Laxness. Laxness was taken from the farm he grew up on, and Kiljan was for the Irish martyr, Saint Killian. At the Abbaye Laxness practiced self-study, studying French, Latin, theology, and philosophy. He also joined a group that was praying for the Nordic countries to convert back to Catholicism.

This religious period didn‚Äôt last long though; from 1927 to 1929, Laxness was living in America and ‚Äúhe became attracted to socialism‚Äù (1). Influenced by this and Upton Sinclair, whom he also befriended, Laxness wrote 1929‚Äôs Al√æ√Ω√∞ub√≥kin (The Book of the People). At this same time Laxness decided to give his go at writing screenplays and moved to Hollywood for a time; he was a big fan of Chaplin‚Äôs film City Lights. In 1929, Laxness faced deportation, probably in part due to his socialism, and ‚ÄúSinclair and Stephen Crane‚Äôs daughter, Helen, intervened‚Äù (2). In the 1940s, Laxness would translate some of Sinclair‚Äôs and Ernest Hemingway‚Äôs works into Icelandic.

Despite, or maybe because of, this, Laxness moved back to Iceland in 1930 where he ‚Äú‚Äòbecame the apostle of the younger generation‚Äô‚Äù (3). Laxness was quite prolific in this period, writing the first two parts of Salka Volka, and F√≥tatak manna (Steps of Man), as well as short story collections and essays. In 1934, Sj√°lfst√¶tt f√≥lk (Independent People) was published. If you‚Äôve heard of Laxness and his work, it‚Äôs probably this book, partly because in 1946 Independent People was chosen as a Book of the Month Club selection and sold over 450,000 in the United States. Because of his socialism and some regard for the Soviet Union, Laxness was investigated by J. Edgar Hoover, and Hoover wanted to keep the royalties Laxness earned out of ‚Äúred Icelandic hands‚Äù (4).

In 1948, Laxness had a house built outside of Mosfellsb√¶r and began a family with his second wife, who also worked as his secretary and manager. At this time the US was developing a permanent military base in Keflavik (about an hour from Reykjavik). They had had a base there during the Second World War and wanted to extend it. Laxness wrote a satirical piece, At√≥mst√∂√∞in (The Atom Station), about this, and it‚Äôs probable that this added to the US‚Äôs dislike of him.

In the 1950s, accolades began to flow in for Laxness. In 1953, he was awarded the World Peace Council Literary Prize, a Soviet-sponsored prize. In 1955, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature ‚Äú‚Äòfor his vivid epic power which has renewed the great narrative art of Iceland‚Äô‚Äù (5). He is Iceland‚Äôs first and only Nobel laureate.

In the 1960s Laxness was active writing and producing plays in Iceland. In 1969 he won the Sonning Prize, a prize ‚Äúawarded biennially for outstanding contributions to European culture‚Äù (6). Throughout the 1970s and 1980s he continued to write essays. As he grew older, though, he developed Alzheimer‚Äôs and moved into a nursing home, where he died at age 95.

Laxness‚Äôs home and garden, Glj√∫frasteinn, is now a museum run by the Icelandic government. One of his daughters is an Oscar-nominated director. A biography of him ‚Äúwon the Icelandic literary prize for best work of non-fiction in 2004‚Äù (7). Laxness‚Äôs legacy lives on in Iceland.

1, 3, 5 ‚Äì Halld√≥r Laxness

2, 4 ‚Äì Richard Rayner, ‚ÄúThe magical and the elemental, from Halld√≥r Laxness,‚Äù Los Angeles Times, January 6, 2008.

6 ‚Äì Sonning Prize

Sorry for the delay in this. I was sick, again, last weekend and spent most of the weekend asleep. By Monday I was a bit better, but since I‚Äôd lost a few days, I didn‚Äôt have this ready then. I like winter, but I‚Äôm over it this year. I haven‚Äôt been sick this much in a while.

I found today‚Äôs topic somewhere on Pinterest. I have a board for historical women, and Zitkala-≈†a is on it. The pin came from a ‚Äúthis day in history‚Äù thing and it‚Äôs for her birthday (February 22). The caption just says ‚ÄúOn this date in 1876, Zitkala Sa was born on the Yankton Indian Reservation in South Dakota. She would go on to write several books, including American Indian Stories, co-write the first Native American opera, and found the National Council of American Indians‚Äù (1). Not a whole lot of information, but just enough to get me interested and wanting to know more.

Zitkala-≈†a was born Gertrude Simmons on February 22, 1876 on the Pine Ridge Reservation, Yankton Sioux Agency, or Yankton Indian Reservation ‚Äì depending on the source ‚Äì in South Dakota. She was the third child of Ellen Simmons, also called Tat√© Iy√≤hiwin (Every Wind or Reaches for the Wind), a Yankton Nakota Sioux. Zitkala-≈†a‚Äôs father was a European-American by the name of Felker, but he abandoned the family when Zitkala-≈†a was young.

Zitkala-≈†a lived on the reservation until she was eight in ‚Äúfreedom and happiness‚Äù (2). In 1884, missionaries arrived at the reservation and Zitkala-≈†a was taken to White‚Äôs Manual Labor Institute in Wabash, Indiana. White‚Äôs was a Quaker school set up to educate the poor and unfortunate so they could do better in life.

While Zitkala-≈†a was only at White‚Äôs for three years, it was hugely important in her life. In The School Days of an Indian Girl, published in 1921, Zitkala-≈†a wrote of the ‚Äúdeep misery of having her heritage stripped away, when she was forced to pray as a Quaker and cut her traditionally long hair, and the contrasting joy of learning to read and write, and to play the violin‚Äù (3).

In 1887, when Zitkala-≈†a returned to the reservation, she didn‚Äôt feel like she belonged anymore, and so, in 1891, she returned to White‚Äôs, wanting more education. White‚Äôs taught girls enough to become house-keepers, but Zitkala-≈†a wanted more than that. She learned piano and violin, and became the music teacher when the previous teacher resigned. It was around this time that Gertrude Simmons adopted the name Zitkala-≈†a (Red Bird) as a way of ‚Äúasserting both her independence from and her ties to Sioux culture‚Äù (4). Zitkala-≈†a is a Lakota name, though she grew up speaking Nakota. One source posits that choosing a Lakota name ‚Äúmight indicate a profound dislocation from her family origins, as well as a conscious choice‚Äù (5).

In 1895, Zitkala-≈†a received her diploma and her mother wanted her to come back home, but Zitkala-≈†a went on to Earlham College in Indiana on a scholarship. At Earlham, though, Zitkala-≈†a felt isolated from her white fellow students. The students only paid attention to her after she gave a speech, ‚ÄúSide by Side‚Äù, and won the Indiana State Oratorical Contest in 1896. Zitkala-≈†a did well at Earlham, but unfortunately had to leave just over a month before graduation due to illness.

Around this same time Zitkala-≈†a began compiling Native American legends. She would translate them into Latin and then English, in the hopes of getting children to read them. Compiling legends would become one of the focuses of Zitkala-≈†a‚Äôs life.

For her violin playing, Zitkala-≈†a received a scholarship to the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston, where she attended from 1897 to 1899. In 1899, she took a position at Carlisle Indian Industrial School in Pennsylvania. Zitkala-≈†a taught music to the children, and ‚Äúconducted debates on the treatment of Native Americans‚Äù (6).

While employed by Carlisle, Zitkala-≈†a played at the 1900 Paris Exposition with the school‚Äôs Indian Band. At this time she also began writing about Native American life, getting published in Harper‚Äôs Monthly, Atlantic Monthly, and others. These articles upset the higher-ups at Carlisle and so she was sent out West, ostensibly to recruit students, but more likely to remove her from the publishing centers in the United States.

When Zitkala-≈†a arrived back out West, she found her mother‚Äôs home in an awful state and her brother‚Äôs family living in poverty. Additionally, there were white settlers on the lands that the Yankton Dakota had been given in 1877 through the Dawes Act (7).

Zitkala-≈†a returned to Carlisle after a while, but upon her return her conflicts with the founder of the school intensified. She didn‚Äôt like that the school focused on assimilating Native students into white culture, and only trained its students for low-level jobs; the school assumed its students would return to where they had come from and that they wouldn‚Äôt need more than a basic education. Carlisle also didn‚Äôt like her stories, calling them ‚Äúworse than pagan‚Äù and ‚Äútrash‚Äù (8).

Due to her continued conflicts with Carlisle, Zitkala-≈†a was dismissed from her position in 1901. She had had an article published in Harper‚Äôs Monthly that year that told of a boy at the school who felt a loss of identity after his education. After being dismissed, Zitkala-≈†a returned home to Yankton, worried for her family. Also at this time, the Native American stories and legends she had been compiling were collected and published in Old Indian Legends, commissioned by a Boston company. Old Indian Legends was published to high acclaim; in 1919 she received a letter of praise for the book from Helen Keller.

Upon returning to Yankton, Zitkala-≈†a took a position as a clerk at the Bureau of Indian Affairs at Standing Rock Indian Reservation. In 1902, Zitkala-≈†a met Captain Raymond Talefase Bonnin; they married later that year. Bonnin was raised Yankton Dakota as well, but was only one quarter to one half Dakota. Shortly after marrying, Bonnin was transferred to Utah; they moved to the Uintah-Ouray Reservation where they lived for fourteen years, and where their only child, Raymond Ohiya Bonnin, was born.

While in Utah, Zitkala-≈†a met William F. Hanson, a professor at Brigham Young University. Hanson was also a composer, and the two began a musical collaboration in 1910. Based on a sacred Sioux ritual that the U.S. government had prohibited from being done on the Utah reservations, The Sun Dance Opera premiered in Vernal, Utah in 1913. Zitkala-≈†a wrote the libretto and the songs for the opera, the first opera co-written by a Native American. In performances, Ute performers danced and played some parts, but all of the lead singing was done by white people. The opera received much praise upon its premiere. It was performed periodically by rural troupes over the years before premiering in New York in 1938. The advertisements in New York only mentioned Hanson.

While in Utah, Zitkala-≈†a joined the Society of American Indians, which was formed in 1911. She served as its secretary until 1916, and edited its journal, American Indian Magazine, from 1918 to 1919. SAI members had to have Indian blood. They were assimilationist, but also promoted Native American self-determination. A main goal was to get full American citizenship for Native Americans. (Towards the end of the twentieth century, SAI was criticized ‚Äúas misguided in their strong advocacy of citizenship and employment rights for Native Americans. Such critics believe that Native Americans have lost cultural identity as they have become more part of mainstream American society.‚Äù [9])

Zitkala-≈†a criticized the Bureau of Indian Affairs for prohibiting Native American children‚Äôs use of their native languages and cultural practices. In the 1920s, Zitkala-≈†a helped promote a pan-Indian movement to help get citizenship rights. In 1924 the Indian Citizenship Act was passed, but it did not secure citizenship for all Native Americans.

In 1926, Zitkala-≈†a and her husband founded the National Council of American Indians. This group, too, worked to unite all Native Americans in a hopes to get full citizenship rights through suffrage. Zitkala-≈†a served as NCAI‚Äôs president, speaker, and major fundraiser from its founding until her death. When the group was revived in 1944, Zitkala-≈†a‚Äôs work was dismissed.

Zitkala-≈†a died on January 26, 1938 in Washington, D.C. She is buried in Arlington National Cemetery due to her husband‚Äôs service in World War One. She is buried as Gertrude Simmons Bonnin. There is a crater on Venus named Bonnin in her honor (all craters on Venus are named for women or have women‚Äôs names).

It‚Äôs agreed that Zitkala-≈†a had two major periods of work. The first is from 1900 to 1904. This period includes the Native American legends and her autobiographical pieces, showing the conflicts between her cultural traditions and assimilation into white culture. Many of these pieces were published in Harper‚Äôs Monthly and Atlantic Monthly. The second period is from 1916 to 1924. These are her political works. Zitkala-≈†a and her family had moved to Washington, D.C., and Zitkala-≈†a became increasingly political on behalf of Native Americans and women.

Some of Zitkala-≈†a‚Äôs most influential works are from this second period. American Indian Stories was published in 1921. She was also co-author of 1923‚Äôs Oklahoma‚Äôs Poor Rich Indians: An Orgy of Graft and Exploitation of the Five Civilized Tribes, Legalized Robbery. Her co-authors were Charles H. Fabens, from the American Indian Defense Association, and Matthew K. Sniffen of the Indian Rights Association. Oklahoma‚Äôs Poor Rich Indians exposed ‚Äúthe corrupt land allocation policies in place at the time in Oklahoma‚Äù (10). This work ‚Äúresulted in her appointment as an advisor to the U.S. government‚Äôs Meriam Commission of 1928, the findings of which eventually led to several important reforms‚Äù (11) and influenced Congress to pass the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934.

Zitkala-≈†a‚Äôs writings were ‚Äúthe first major literary pieces written by a Native American in English that deal with Native American culture and the process of assimilation from an Indian‚Äôs point of view‚Äù (12). She‚Äôs so interesting. I‚Äôm going to have to read some of her writings now, many of which are available online.

When I have no idea what to write about, or am coming up with too many ideas and can‚Äôt narrow them down, I ask other people what or who they would want me to look up and write about. That‚Äôs how I did the Eastern State Penitentiary piece (hi mom!) and that‚Äôs how we have today‚Äôs post, courtesy of my husband. Today‚Äôs is tricky (I think that‚Äôs part of why he picked it). I fully admit that I usually start by Googling the topic or looking at Wikipedia. I always try and find that information elsewhere, but Wikipedia is actually a pretty good place to start for basic information; some of their articles are even starred or locked, showing their accuracy. Today‚Äôs topic, Elihu Palmer, had a stub on Wikipedia. Oooookay‚Ä¶ Everywhere I looked had similar information, but with some extra tidbits here and there, so we‚Äôre going to see how well I pulled something together from little information.

Elihu Palmer was born in 1764 in Canterbury, Connecticut. That‚Äôs about all we known about him until he was in his twenties. Already having issues learning about him‚Ä¶ When he was growing up, though, we know what was going on in the country. We weren‚Äôt the United States yet, but we were getting there. The country would be founded without explicit religion, and with the idea that all religions could be practiced free of persecution. Many of the Founding Fathers were deists, believing that the natural world and reason and observation were all one needed to determine if there was a god or not.

Unitarianism was also gaining in popularity at this time. Unitarianism is a branch of Protestantism that believes in one god, not the Trinity like Catholics believe in. They also believe that Jesus is not God himself, but human, though could possibly still be considered a savior. In 1782 the first recognized Unitarian church opened in the United States in Boston, Massachusetts. Unitarians were a very liberal branch of Christianity and the Enlightenment helped their beliefs gain popularity. All of this is to say that even among ministers, some very radical ideas were emerging, and some of them broke with religion altogether.

Elihu Palmer studied to be a Presbyterian minister at Dartmouth, and graduated in 1787, taking a position in what is now Queens in New York. Within a year, though, Palmer was dismissed from his position. In 1789, he moved to Philadelphia and joined a Baptist Church. Ultimately, though, the Baptists too kicked him out. In both of these cases, it seems that Palmer had begun speaking in more deist terms, and against the divinity of Jesus. Palmer then ‚Äúbecame somewhat of a physical, spiritual, and intellectual wanderer‚Äù (1).

Palmer wound up in New York City where he became a Universalist, but also publicly rejected Jesus‚Äôs divinity, which wasn‚Äôt part of Universalist beliefs. Palmer and his wife worked for deism and his ideas began to gain traction. He even planned speeches challenging Jesus‚Äôs divinity, and published ads for them in the local papers (2). With all of his outspokenness though, Palmer and his followers were banned from Philadelphia.

Palmer decided to become a lawyer, and passed the Pennsylvania bar in 1793. Despite having been banned, he returned to Philadelphia. This was a fateful decision. In 1793, a yellow fever epidemic broke out in Philadelphia. Over five thousand people died, Palmer‚Äôs wife being one of those who died. Palmer survived, but was blinded. ‚ÄúHis enemies naturally saw his blindness as God‚Äôs punishment for heresy‚Äù (3), even though there were many religious people who died in the epidemic as well.

After his blinding, Palmer couldn‚Äôt practice law anymore, and so became a travelling lecturer for deism. His first stop was in Augusta, Georgia and he was received favorably, or at least cordially. Georgia had based their separation of church and state rules on Virginia‚Äôs religious freedom act (4). While in Augusta, Palmer also helped to collect ‚Äúmaterials for Dr. Jedidiah Morse‚Äôs ‚ÄòGeography‚Äô‚Äù (5); Morse wrote geography textbooks, and his son would create Morse Code.

After lecturing in Georgia, Palmer moved back to Philadelphia, and then on to New York, still lecturing throughout the East Coast. Palmer‚Äôs first speech in New York took place on Christmas Day. Palmer believed this was a day ‚Äúwell suited to the denunciation of both Christianity and Christ‚Äù (6). In New York in 1796, Palmer formed the Deistical Society of New York.

Palmer was an extreme deist, though, holding positions that many did not. He believed that ‚Äúthe flawed teachings of Jesus were responsible for Christianity‚Äôs sordid history‚Äù (7) and that belief in supernatural experiences ‚Äúundermines nature‚Äôs principles and furthers human misery by setting up unreasonable expectations‚Äù (8). He believed in natural philosophy and criticized institutional Christianity. Palmer was a close friend of Thomas Paine, but his beliefs were much more extreme than Paine‚Äôs. Paine believed there were still ethical things in the New Testament and that there was virtue in the teachings of Jesus (9). The two wrote similarly though, being incredibly honest about their beliefs and pulling no punches. Palmer, though, didn‚Äôt care about what others believed if they were against his beliefs.

Despite his abrasiveness, Palmer was popular and was important for secularism in the young country. Deism was largely seen as only for educated and/or upper-class people. Palmer brought deism down to a level that was accessible for everyone. The Deistical Society he formed in New York, as well as in Philadelphia and Baltimore, had members that were shopkeepers and artisans. ‚ÄúWith the exception of doctors, almost no members of learned professions were recorded as members‚Äù (J). Palmer founded two newspapers in 1800 and 1803; the only reason the papers had to stop publication was because the subscribers couldn‚Äôt pay their bills on time, not because there was a lack of subscribers.

In addition to his speeches, Palmer wrote. He wrote the speeches he gave, he wrote pieces for his and others‚Äô newspapers, and he wrote a book, Principles of Nature, published first in 1801. In Principles of Nature, Palmer reiterated his belief that ‚Äú‚Äòthe world in infinitely worse‚Äô for following Jesus‚Äù (10). Palmer believed it was the ‚Äúnonreligious advances in human thought‚Äù (11) which led to the creation of the printing press and eventually to the Enlightenment and the American and French Revolutions. He believed the Enlightenment had allowed for the enfranchisement of men ‚Äúwho had never before been considered fit to govern themselves‚Äù (12).

Principles of Nature had sold out three editions by the time of Palmer‚Äôs death in 1806 at 42 while on a speaking tour. Upon his death, his widow (he remarried shortly after the death of his first wife) was left without property or money and only made due with the help of Thomas Paine. Principles of Nature was still being published after Palmer‚Äôs death. In 1819, the London publisher Richard Carlile published it with help from his wife while he was in prison for having published other scandalous or heretical books. In 1824, two booksellers went to prison for three years each for selling Principles of Nature and The Age of Reason.

That‚Äôs Elihu Palmer. Still not a whole lot of information about him, but I‚Äôve tried to do the best I could. Even though we don‚Äôt know a lot about him personally, and his seeming abrasiveness led to some unpopularity, I think he‚Äôs important to know and know about. Like mentioned earlier, he helped bring deism and Enlightenment ideas to those who maybe hadn‚Äôt heard of it. He laid foundations for freethinking and secularism in the United States, even if we don‚Äôt know his name. I‚Äôm glad my husband suggested him.

Apologies for the lack of post last week. I was behind to begin with, I got halfway through typing up my notes but I was feeling horrible, and wound up spending all day in bed instead of doing anything at all productive. üò¶ But here we are this week with the post I should‚Äôve written for last week. Hopefully that won‚Äôt happen again.

This week we have a Nobel Prize winner in literature for a book I‚Äôve been wanting to read for a while (I finally picked it up last weekend!), Sigrid Undset. Sigrid was born at her mother‚Äôs childhood home in Kalundborg, Denmark on May 20, 1882. She was the oldest of three daughters of Charlotte Undset (n√©e Anna Maria Charlotte Gyth) and Ingvald Martin Undset, a Norwegian architect. When Sigrid was two, her family moved to Kristiana, Norway (what is now Oslo; the name changed in 1925).

When Sigrid was eleven, her father died after a prolonged illness. This put the family in financial trouble, and Sigrid had to give up her hopes of going to university. Instead, Sigrid enrolled in a one year secretarial course, and at age sixteen went to work for an engineering company in Kristiana; she would work there for ten years.

Throughout this time, Sigrid was writing fiction. When she was sixteen she had started a novel set in Denmark in the Middle Ages. This was completed by age twenty-two, but it was turned down by the publishers she approached. Two years later, Sigrid had a new manuscript; it was only eighty pages and was set in contemporary Kristiana, focusing on a middle-class woman. This too was turned down at first, but was then published. The work, Fru Maria Oulie, created a stir upon its publication; the opening line reads ‚ÄúI have been unfaithful to my husband‚Äù and scandalized its readers with its frank discussion of adultery.

The publication of Fru Maria Oulie made Sigrid Undset a ‚Äúpromising young author in Norway‚Äù (1). In 1907 she joined the Norwegian Authors‚Äô Union; in the 1930s she would head their Literary Council and was one of their chairmen as well.

From the time Fru Maria Oulie was published in 1907 until 1919, Sigrid wrote about life in contemporary Kristiana, ‚Äúabout the city and its inhabitants,‚Äù ‚Äúworking people, of trivial family destinies, of the relationship between parents and children‚Äù (2). She focused a lot on women and who and how they loved. In 1911 Jenny was published, and in 1914 Varren (Spring) was published. All of her works sold well immediately, and after her third book was published, she was able to quit her office job to write full time.

Sigrid was given a writer‚Äôs scholarship and travelled throughout Europe. She went to Denmark, Germany, and Italy, where she spent nine months in Rome. Her parents had loved Rome and she spent her time travelling to all the same places she knew her parents had visited. In Rome there was a group of Scandinavian writers and artists and Sigrid made friends with them.

In Rome in 1909, Sigrid met the Norwegian painter Anders Castus Svarstad. He was nine years older, and was married with three children, but they fell in love. They waited three years for Anders‚Äôs divorce to finalize, and then married in 1912. They travelled to London for six months and then came back to Rome where their first child was born in January 1913. The child was a boy, named for his father. By 1919, Sigrid had had another child, a mentally handicapped daughter, and had taken in Anders‚Äôs other three children, including a mentally handicapped son.

Throughout this time, Sigrid continued writing, working on more novels and some short stories. She also entered public debates, critical of women‚Äôs issues, and the moral and ethical issues she saw that had led to the First World War.

In late 1919, Sigrid moved to Lillehammer, Norway with her two children, and pregnant with her third. The plan was for Sigrid to rest in Lillehammer while hers and Anders‚Äô home was being built in Kristiana. However, the marriage broke up and the couple divorced before their home was completed. Sigrid stayed in Lillehammer and her third child was born there in August of that year.

Within two years, though, the home that was being built was completed. Bjerkeb√¶k was a large home with traditional Norwegian architecture. It had a ‚Äúlarge fenced garden with views of the town and the villages around‚Äù (3).

While the home was being completed, Sigrid worked on a Norwegian retelling of the King Arthur myth. She also ‚Äústudied Old Norse manuscripts and Medieval chronicles and visited and examined Medieval monasteries, both at home and abroad‚Äù, becoming ‚Äúan authority on the period ‚Ä¶ and a very different person from the 22-year-old who had written her first novel about the Middle Ages‚Äù (4). Her works are ‚Äúprecise, realistic, and never romanticized‚Äù (5), showing true human emotions, just set in a different time period. By using the Middle Ages, she was able to give herself the necessary distance, but also allowed for her admiration of Medieval Christendom.

The work this research led to is Krisin Lavransdatter, a trilogy published between 1920 and 1922. The trilogy shows ‚Äúlife in Scandinavia in the Middle Ages, portrayed through the experiences of a woman from birth until death‚Äù (6). In addition to the attention to detail about the historical period she was writing about, Sigrid employed modernist techniques such as stream of consciousness in Kristin Lavransdatter; these were cut out of the first English translations of the work though.

Around this same period, Sigrid became a Catholic. Her parents had been atheists and her upbringing was secular, though living in a Lutheran country she had been baptized and had attended Lutheran church growing up. With the outbreak of the First World War and the break-up of her marriage, Sigrid had had a crisis of faith, and Catholicism was the answer for her. In 1924, at age 42, Sigrid was received into the Catholic Church and also became a lay Dominican.

Sigrid‚Äôs conversion was scandalous at the time in Norway. As mentioned, Norway was a Lutheran country; almost no one practiced Catholicism. There was also a lot of anti-Catholic rhetoric in the country at the time. As an author, Sigrid was also part of the intelligentsia at the time. They too didn‚Äôt accept her though, being mostly socialist and communist themselves. Sigrid was open about her Catholicism though, defending the Catholic Church in public debates.

Her next work after Kristin Lavransdatter was Olav Audunss√∏n (translated in English as The Master of Hestviken). Olav, a four volume novel, was written during her conversion and published right after; it takes place during a time period when Norway was a Catholic country. After Olav, Sigrid went back to writing contemporary books, set in Oslo and ‚Äúwith a strong Catholic element‚Äù (7). In 1928 Sigrid won the Nobel Prize for Literature ‚Äúprincipally for her powerful descriptions of Northern life during the Middle Ages‚Äù (8).

Following this, Sigrid was translating the Icelandic Sagas into Modern Norwegian and writing literary essays on English literature, mainly on the Bront√´s and D. H. Lawrence. In 1934 she published Eleven Years Old, an autobiographical piece about her childhood in Kristiana. In the 1930s she was also starting a new historical piece, this time to be set in eighteenth century Scandinavia, but only one volume was published before World War Two broke out. After the war Sigrid was too broken herself to finish writing it.

With World War Two came a lot of changes in Sigrid‚Äôs part of the world. Stalin invaded Finland; Sigrid donated her Nobel Prize to the Finnish war effort. In 1940 Germany invaded Norway. Throughout the 1930s Sigrid had been critical of Hitler, and so fled Norway upon the German invasion. She and her son first went to Sweden and then to the United States; they lived in Brooklyn and she pleaded for help for her country and for the Jews. In 1940, also, her oldest son, Anders, was killed in battle (her daughter had died before the war broke out).

After World War Two ended, Sigrid returned to Norway, but never wrote again. Sigrid Undset died in Lillehammer on June 10, 1949 at age 67. She is buried in Mesnali, east of Lillehammer. The son and daughter that predeceased her are buried there as well; there are three black crosses marking their graves.

Sigrid Undset has been honored in many ways. In addition to the Nobel Prize in 1928, there is a crater on Venus named Undset for her. She was on the 500 kronur note and a 1982 2 kronur postage stamp in Norway. In 1998, Sweden put her on a stamp as well. Her home of Bjerkeb√¶k is now a part of the Maihaugen museum.

The book I finally got of Sigrid Undset‚Äôs is Kristin Lavransdatter, but now I‚Äôm interested in her other works. I think her books about contemporary Norway would be really interesting, reading about how Norway was in the early twentieth century, especially Fru Maria Oulie and its controversial opening line. I‚Äôm also now interested in her more Catholic novels, though I‚Äôd wait and read those after I‚Äôd read her earlier works. (While I love Evelyn Waugh‚Äôs Brideshead Revisited, I wish I had read it after I‚Äôd read his earlier works. He went through a similar conversion to Catholicism and it becomes more and more prevalent in his works.) I hope I‚Äôve inspired you all to go find some Sigrid Undset books as well!

This post came a bit last minute (so it should be shorter at least!). I was researching someone else (they‚Äôll be up next week), and then realized that it was almost the birthday of the other person I‚Äôd considered for this week, as in, this person would have turned 125 tomorrow. So, I changed my plan and rushed to finish this. So Happy Day-Early Birthday to Agatha Christie, one of my favorites.

Agatha Christie was born Agatha Mary Clarissa Miller in Torquay, Devon, England on September 15, 1890. Her family was comfortably middle class, and her father, an American, homeschooled Agatha; her mother, Clara, didn‚Äôt want Agatha to learn to read until she was eight. Agatha was the only child in the house (she had two older siblings, but ‚Äúwas a much loved ‚Äòafter thought‚Äô‚Äù (1)) and was bored, so she taught herself to read by age five.

Agatha read children‚Äôs stories that were popular at the time, including E. Nesbit and Louisa May Alcott, but also read poetry and ‚Äúthrillers from America‚Äù (2). When Agatha was five, her family spent some time in France; this is when Agatha first learned French. When Agatha was eleven, her father died after a number of heart attacks.

When Agatha was eighteen, she began writing short stories; some of these would be published in the 1930s after serious revisions. Two years later, Agatha traveled with her mother to Cairo for her mother‚Äôs health. They stayed for three months at the Gezirah Palace Hotel. During this period Agatha went to house parties galore and had a number of marriage proposals, none of which she accepted.

In 1912, Agatha met Archie Christie, an aviator with the Royal Flying Corps. They had a whirlwind romance, and wanted to marry, but neither had the money to make it possible. When World War One broke out, Archie went to serve in France and Agatha worked at the Voluntary Aid Department at the Red Cross Hospital in Torquay. They decided not to put off marrying any longer, and married on Christmas Eve of 1914. Archie returned to France on the 27th.

Throughout the war, Agatha and Archie didn‚Äôt see much of each other. In January 1918, though, Archie was posted to the War Office in London, and so they were finally together again; this is when ‚ÄúAgatha felt her married life truly began‚Äù (3).

Throughout the war, Agatha had been writing. She started in earnest on a bet from her sister ‚Äúthat she couldn‚Äôt write a good detective story‚Äù (4), as well as to relieve some of the monotony at work. Agatha would first develop her plot and then came up with her characters. At this time she was working at the Hospital Dispensary. She had had to take and pass a test from the Society of Apothecaries in order to get that position. This gave her the background she needed when she would use poisons in her writing. Her use of poison in her first book ‚Äúwas so well described that when the book was eventually published Agatha received an unprecedented honour for a writer of fiction ‚Äì a review in the Pharmaceutical Journal‚Äù (5).

This first book, The Mysterious Affair at Styles, was published in 1919. This was a big year for Agatha; in addition to the book‚Äôs publication, she and Archie moved to London, and their daughter Rosalind was born. The publication of Styles came after having sent it to four other publishers. This publisher, John Lane of Bodley Head, suggested a couple of changes to the book, including moving the resolution of the story from a courtroom to the, now famous, library.

The Mysterious Affair at Styles is the first book to feature Hercule Poirot, a Belgian former policeman. During World War One, a lot of Belgian refugees came to England; this is why Agatha Christie made Poirot a Belgian refugee.

After the war, Agatha continued writing. Tommy and Tuppence Beresford and Miss Jane Marple soon followed Hercule Poirot. Agatha kept writing, even while she was travelling with Archie, ‚Äúpromoting the Empire Exhibition of 1924‚Äù (6). Agatha received news that The Secret Adversary (her second book, the first Tommy and Tuppence) would be published while she was in Cape Town. (While in Cape Town, also, Agatha became the first British woman to surf standing up.)

Agatha used inspiration from her travels with Archie, as well as people she knew. For her fourth book, The Man in the Brown Suit, Agatha based Sir Eustace Padlar on Archie‚Äôs boss. For publication of this book, Agatha switched from Bodley Head to William Collins and Sons (now HarperColins).

Around this time, Agatha and Archie returned to England to their daughter. They named their new home in the suburbs of London, Styles, after her first book. Shortly after this, Agatha‚Äôs life hit a hard spot. Agatha‚Äôs mother died, leaving Agatha to empty out the family home in Torquay. She was working on a novel at this point, but the strain of her mother‚Äôs death also strained her writing.

At this same time, 1926, Archie fell in love with Nancy Neale. Archie golfed, Nancy golfed, Agatha did not. Agatha found out about Archie‚Äôs relationship with Nancy. In early December of that year, Agatha left Rosalind with the maids at home and left. Her car was found several miles away, and a nationwide search took place. Finally she was found to have travelled from Kings Cross to Harrogate to the Harrogate Spa Hotel. Agatha was staying at the hotel as Theresa Neale, from South Africa. Luckily the staff at the hotel had recognized her and had called the police. Agatha didn‚Äôt recognize Archie, and didn‚Äôt know who she was, when he came to get her; she had amnesia and possibly a concussion. Agatha never spoke of this time with anyone.

After her disappearance, Agatha separated from Archie. She moved to London with Rosalind and with her secretary, Carlo. She underwent psychological treatments at this time. Agatha was struggling financially, and was having trouble writing. Her brother-in-law suggested collecting some previously written Poirot short stories and publishing them; these short stories were published as The Big Four.

In 1928, Agatha and Archie‚Äôs divorce was finalized, and Agatha went to the Canary Islands with Rosalind. She finally finished The Mystery of the Blue Train, the story she had been struggling with after her mother‚Äôs death. In late 1928, Giant‚Äôs Beard was published; this was her first book as Mary Westmacott. Agatha would write six romances as Mary Westmacott (in addition to the sixty-six novels and fourteen collections of short stories as herself).

In the autumn of 1928, Agatha finally travelled on the Orient Express, something she had always wanted to do. She also travelled to Baghdad and to the archeological site at Ur, making friends with the Woolleys, the people who ran the site. The following year, Agatha came back to the dig and met 25-year-old Max Mallowan, and archeologist in training. Max showed Agatha around the site and ‚Äúeach found the other‚Äôs company relaxing‚Äù (7).

Max and Agatha fell in love, their relationship ‚Äúforged by travel‚Äù (8). Max proposed to Agatha on the last night of his trip to Ashfield, her family home. They were married on September 11, 1930. Max and Agatha spent their summers at Ashfield, springs on archeological digs, and the rest of the year in London or at their home in Wallingford, Oxfordshire.

Throughout most of her marriage to Max, Agatha was writing two or three books a year. When they were on Max‚Äôs digs, she would write ‚Äúa chapter or two during quiet mornings and helped out on site in the afternoon‚Äù (9). Many of Agatha‚Äôs Middle Eastern themed or placed books came out of this period.

In 1938, Agatha and Max bought Greenway House on the River Dart to replace Ashfield. During World War Two, though, the home was taken over by Americans. Agatha also worried they‚Äôd have to sell Greenway House in order to pay taxes. During the war, Max was in Cairo, using his knowledge of languages to assist the war effort; Agatha stayed in London, doing much as she did during the First World War, volunteering at the dispensary at University College Hospital, and writing. Agatha wrote N or M? as a patriotic gesture at this time, but the publication of the book was delayed so it didn‚Äôt quite have the effect she‚Äôd have liked.

With Max gone, and there being so much less to do, Agatha‚Äôs output during the Second World War was prolific. Between 1939 and 1945, Agatha published twelve books under both her name and as Mary Westmacott. In 1946, her cover as Westmacott was blown and she stopped using that name; she had ‚Äúenjoyed the freedom to write without the pressure of being Agatha Christie‚Äù (10).

After the war, Agatha‚Äôs output slowed. She had Max back, and the tax implications of her writing were just too much. Throughout the rest of the 40s and 50s, she worked on theatrical productions, and less on books. (Though she would continue to publish throughout the rest of her life, she wasn‚Äôt putting out multiple books a year anymore, and some years would publish nothing.)

One of her theatrical contributions was The Mousetrap. Premiering in the West End on November 25, 1952, The Mousetrap is the world‚Äôs longest running play, never having ceased performance since then. It has been performed over 25,000 times.

Agatha‚Äôs last public appearance was at the premiere for the 1974 film of Murder on the Orient Express, with Albert Finney. Agatha liked the film but thought Poirot‚Äôs mustaches ‚Äúweren‚Äôt luxurious enough‚Äù (11).

Agatha Christie Mallowan died on January 12, 1976. She is buried at St. Mary‚Äôs, Cholsey, near Wallingford.

Agatha Christie holds a number of records for her works. As mentioned, The Mousetrap is the world‚Äôs longest running play. She‚Äôs also in the Guinness Book of World Records as the best selling novelist of all time, with over two billion copies of her books in print. She is the world‚Äôs third most-published author, behind only Shakespeare and the Bible. She is the most translated individual, having been translated into 103 languages. And And Then There Were None (first published in 1939) is the best selling mystery novel in the world, and one of the best selling books ever, with 100 million sales.

That‚Äôs Agatha Christie, quick and not super in depth, but hopefully fun. I love Agatha Christie, I love Poirot (David Suchet forever!) and Miss Marple. I wanted to do something about her for her 125th birthday, and so many other events in her life happened in September, I thought why not. I‚Äôll probably wind up rereading some Agatha Christie tomorrow, or maybe finally read The Mysterious Affair at Styles (surprisingly hard to track down‚Ä¶). Happy early birthday, Agatha!
